awd_titl_txt: Math Practice for Physics: Building Math Fluency in an Introductory Undergraduate Physics Context
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the NSF Improving Undergraduate STEM Education Program: Education and Human Resources (IUSE: EHR), this project aims to serve the national interest by improving math fluency in introductory physics courses. The goal is to use research-based principles, together with methods from cognitive psychology and education research,  to develop, implement, and assess a set of practice assignments called Math Practice. Math Practice is based on Essential Skills, an existing online platform used at Ohio State University. The initial scope of this project is to advance knowledge about how to address students' difficulties with math skills that are needed for success in introductory physics courses.  This initial work will involve the 15,000 students in introductory physics courses at the target schools. However, because this intervention is both low-cost and logistically simple to implement, it could potentially improve performance and retention of the 500,000 students enrolled each year in physics classes nationwide. Furthermore, although the Math Practice application will be designed to help all students, it is likely to especially help underprepared students succeed and continue in physics courses. 

The design of this proposed intervention is based on well-established research-based learning methods, including spaced and interleaved mastery practice with immediate feedback. This method is expected to automate and thereby reduce the cognitive load involved in applying basic math procedures in physics. Reducing cognitive load is important since physics tends to have complex, perceptually rich notation and contexts. The experimental design will include control conditions and "A/B testing" to explore optimal practice tasks and formats, such as comparison of alternative solutions and combinations of generic and context-rich format practice. The assessments will include validated math instruments, course performance, and motivational survey scales. These assessments will be used for iterative improvement of materials, investigation of areas of student difficulty, and investigation of potentially important student-level factors of performance and motivation. As a result, the practice tasks and assignment design will have a strong empirical and theoretical basis. Further, this project is expected to advance knowledge about student difficulties with essential math skills and the mechanisms underlying these difficulties, in an introductory physics context. In addition, it is expected to advance knowledge of the effectiveness of several specific kinds of empirically and theoretically promising math practice tasks. Finally, the project is expected to determine the extent to which student characteristics and  motivations interact with this intervention. Thus, it will potentially provide information about the mechanisms of the difficulties and additional avenues for productive interventions. Given that math is essential in all STEM disciplines, the information learned in this project could potentially extend to all of STEM education. For example, the difficulties students have with symbolic notation in introductory physics are also likely to be encountered in other areas of STEM. The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students. Through the Engaged Student Learning track, the program supports the creation, exploration, and implementation of promising practices and tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project has employed education research-based methods to substantially expand and improve STEM Fluency, a fledgling online learning application designed to improve university-level students’ fluency with basic skills critical for success in STEM courses. Fluency in such skills can improve learning, retention, and success, especially for students interested in STEM careers, where there are significant workforce needs.  We highlight the outcomes of this project below.

First, we iteratively designed, implemented, and assessed over 2000 new items in over 30 practice categories for STEM Fluency practice. This included problems in algebra and trigonometry relevant to physics, and often using physics symbols, and drawing vectors on a grid (e.g., using a mouse), which allows for richer student engagement and better assessment and training of skills like vector addition and subtraction.

Second, we implemented STEM Fluency for a large number of students at several universities. At Ohio State University, where the bulk of the project took place, we implemented weekly STEM Fluency graded assignments to over 15,000 students in introductory physics courses at Ohio State University from Autumn 2019 to Spring 2023. During this time, we collected performance data, and STEM Fluency functioned quite well: we continue to use STEM Fluency assignments in the courses.

We have begun to work with instructors at other institutions, demonstrating that this application and method can be broadly used. Instructors at several other institutions are using STEM Fluency (formerly known as Essential Skills before expansion beyond OSU). This includes University of Washington (Seattle and a regional campus), University of Colorado, Arizona State University regional campus, US Air Force Academy, Bowling Green (intro tech ed course) and University of Utah. STEM Fluency has the potential for widespread use in physics courses around the nation and world, and has materials commonly used in intro courses and intermediate courses. It also has the potential to expand to higher levels and other disciplines. In fact, materials for 2nd year physics courses at OSU have also been developed and implemented for over 500 additional physics majors.  The departments of Chemistry and Astronomy have also created content and are implementing it every year (~100-200 students).

Third, using educational research methods, we have found that STEM Fluency practice is effective. We designed and conducted 11 control-treatment studies and found significant increases in accuracy and fluency during practice. Pre and post-testing also indicates significant gains in skills, especially for students who initially score low, and STEM Fluency practice also closes the initial performance gap between male and female students on accuracy in basic STEM skills. Further, we see clear positive effects of STEM Fluency practice on exam performance, but some results are nuanced. For example, short, weekly, basic skills practice in algebra helps students (about 0.1-0.2 SD on exam scores), but the effect seems to be greatest for those who have first gained high accuracy in algebra, and then improve on speed.

                Fourth, the STEM Fluency application allows for research into the importance of speed for success in introductory physics courses, and we have found that speed and changes in speed is associated with overall course performance. This opens up a new line of research into how we might consider speed (i.e. advantages and disadvantages of encouraging or testing for speed) when designing instruction and assessments in STEM courses and ultimately helping all students to learn and become more fluent in STEM skills and comfortable and with STEM.

                         Fifth, this project has produced numerous outcomes associated with dissemination. First, we have created the STEMFluency.org website which allows multiple universities to create, implement and manage assignments to students and for students to complete STEM Fluency assignments, and we also have a public version that is in the process of building for broad and free participation to all interested. This project has led to the creation of a non-profit organization called STEM Fluency, that has the goal of expanding the use of this learning application to institutions across the nation. Next, we have published 2 papers in the journal Physical Review Physics Education Research, and we have 2 more that are near completion, to be submitted in March-April 2024, and at least 1 more submitted by the end of 2024. Next, we have presented results at national conferences (9 presentations, 3 posters; American Association of Physics Teachers, American Physical Society). By building collaborations, this project has spun off more research with 3 NSF grants that use and further develop STEM Fluency and conduct research on student learning and motivation. Finally, this project was the primary support for a graduate student, who obtained her PhD in Physics based on work on this NSF project, and another graduate student is working on this project who will also earn his PhD from, in part, work on this project. Three undergraduate students have also worked on the project.
